description:
The provided text discusses the application of a specific method used for collecting macroinvertebrates from river bottoms, referred to as a "2-m beam trawl." This technique involves towing a trawl with a 2-meter long beam along the river bed for a specified distance. Macroinvertebrates are organisms that are large enough to be seen with the naked eye and inhabit the benthic zone, or the bottom layer of a body of water.

The 2-m beam trawl method is an essential tool used in calculating the density of benthic organisms. Density is determined by counting the number of organisms collected during the sampling process and dividing that count by the area sampled. This information is critical for identifying suitable habitats and monitoring trends in population abundance over time.

The beam trawl consists of a rectangular frame with a 2-meter long beam, equipped with a cod end, which is the bag or container at the bottom of the trawl where the collected organisms are stored. When towed along the river bed, the trawl collects a representative sample of macroinvertebrates from the benthic zone.

The efficiency and effectiveness of this method depend on factors such as water depth, current velocity, sediment type, and trawl design. A well-designed and calibrated 2-m beam trawl will provide reliable density data when used consistently over time and across different sampling sites.

In summary, the 2-m beam trawl method is a widely used technique for collecting macroinvertebrates from river bottoms. It involves towing a 2-meter long beam trawl along the river bed to sample organisms in the benthic zone. The data collected using this method can be used to determine density, which is essential for habitat identification and population trend analysis.
